title: (x) substitute for Helvetica Neue - various {gang}
content:
I am currently looking for a typeface that would substitute for Helvetica Neue Light (45 ?).   
   
I am a cheapster, however, I do buy fonts from time to time. Since this typeface will have a very short run in a web piece, are there any typefaces you can suggest that I could find free that would have the same look as Helvetica Neue Light.   
   
Thank you.
author: anonymous

comments.content: Actually, it would help if I read your post. Arial doesn't have the style-y thin weights. I got a copy of Peter Bruhn's Eric Sans when I registered with Veer. It's light & has a hell of a lot more style than Helvetica.

Just buy the Prochez's Parisine or Parisine +.   
   
 [http://www.typofonderie.com/Alphabets/ParisinePlus.asp](http://web.archive.org/web/20130118042934/http:/www.typofonderie.com/Alphabets/ParisinePlus.asp)   
 [http://www.typofonderie.com/Alphabets/Parisine.asp](http://web.archive.org/web/20130118042934/http:/www.typofonderie.com/Alphabets/Parisine.asp)

[what is a good substitute for Helvetica?   
....Advil   
 ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20130118042934im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif) ]

How about [Paris 1960](http://web.archive.org/web/20130118042934/http:/houseind.com/house.php?kit=CHALET-FO&sub=view), part of House's Chalet collection?   
   
(I can't believe I just now got the connection between "house" and "chalet." Should I even admit that?)
Oh, sorry, I missed the part where you wanted something for free. I think you should spend a little cash and get something well done. You'll use it again, I'm sure.

Chesh, I agree Mordecai would be better off buying fonts, but we don't know what his financial situation is. I'm sure he will find something that is functual on a freeware site. The thing he didn't ask for and I will applaud (clap, clap, clap, bet you didn't think I could do it with one hand) him, is he didn't ask anyone here to send him commercial fonts directly.

It doesn't really look like the Helveticas you mentioned, but check out Graham Meade's free, super-slim [_Walkway_ family](http://web.archive.org/web/20130118042934/http:/www.moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/gemnew/home.htm?w01.htm~mainFrame) of 51 fonts. Can choosers of freeware be picky?

edit:   
   
Sorry bout the edit...but I think what I am really looking for would be something that looks like the following:   
   
Helvetica 35 Thin   
Helvetica 25 Ultra Light   
and   
Helvetica 45 Light   
   
Thanks again.

[Disco](http://web.archive.org/web/20130118042934/http:/www.typografski.de/pages/fonts.html) by Typografski. It's Helvomita-esque. It's anorexia-thin.   
And it's <blink>FREE</blink>! ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20130118042934im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)
I really can't bring myself to like this face. ![:-(](http://web.archive.org/web/20130118042934im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/sad.gif)
